prompt: Evaluate how memory is reconstructed and how this affects the reliability of eyewitness testimony. Your response should refer to relevant cognitive theories and experimental studies (e.g., Loftus & Palmer). Consider implications for the legal system and include real or hypothetical examples.

criteria.name: Understanding of Memory Reconstruction
criteria.description: Demonstrates conceptual understanding of how memory is reconstructed and the cognitive processes involved.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Clearly explains reconstructive memory using cognitive models and includes terminology like schema, misinformation effect, and retrieval cues.
performance_descriptors.good: Demonstrates solid understanding, though one or two concepts may lack depth.
performance_descriptors.average: Covers key ideas but lacks precision or completeness.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Limited explanation or use of incorrect terms.

criteria.name: Integration of Research Evidence
criteria.description: Refers to and explains relevant cognitive psychology studies and their findings.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Integrates at least two relevant studies (e.g., Loftus & Palmer) with detailed discussion of results and implications.
performance_descriptors.good: Refers to relevant studies with some interpretation.
performance_descriptors.average: Mentions studies without sufficient explanation or connection.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Minimal or unclear reference to studies.

criteria.name: Legal and Real-World Application
criteria.description: Explores how reconstructive memory affects the accuracy of eyewitness testimony and the justice system.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Applies theory to real/hypothetical legal scenarios; discusses implications for court procedures or witness reliability.
performance_descriptors.good: Makes appropriate links to legal context; examples may be basic.
performance_descriptors.average: Some application present, but lacks clarity or insight.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Weak or vague reference to real-world implications.

criteria.name: Structure, Tone, and Referencing
criteria.description: Maintains academic clarity, organization, and APA citation.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Well-structured, clearly written, formal tone, accurate APA referencing.
performance_descriptors.good: Generally organized with minor writing or citation issues.
performance_descriptors.average: Some inconsistency in tone or referencing.

key_points: Define reconstructive memory and how it differs from simple recall.
Explain schema theory and how it influences memory reconstruction.
Discuss the misinformation effect and its impact on eyewitness accuracy.
Analyze findings from studies such as Loftus & Palmer car crash experiment.
Apply these findings to legal scenarios, like courtroom testimony or police interviews.
Discuss implications for legal reform (e.g., use of cognitive interviews, jury instructions).
Use academic tone, structured writing, and APA-style referencing.
llm_questions: What is reconstructive memory and how does it affect the reliability of recall?
How do schemas influence what people remember or misremember?
Can you explain the Loftus and Palmer (1974) experiment on eyewitness testimony?
What is the misinformation effect and how does it work?
How can memory distortion influence the outcome of legal trials?
What are some methods used to reduce memory distortion in eyewitnesses?
Can you suggest a clear outline for an essay on memory and eyewitness reliability?
How do I cite psychological experiments in APA format?
